sentence: No reads detected at all.; Good afternoon,. I've been using `fastp` successfully without issue for several months now, but suddenly the program will not process/recognize any reads at all. I have attempted this with both gzipped and uncompressed fastq files with the same results. I even tested this on fastq files that were successfully trimmed with fastp several months ago and it fails. . File format from `head -4 filename`. ```. @HISEQ:349:C9CG2ANXX:2:1101:1389:1976 1:N:0:TCCTAT. TTCCCTTTCTTCCAGTGAAATGACCCGACAACAATTGAAATAGATTATTTCATGGTGCATATGCGGGAGTAATGAACGATATAAATATTAAACCAGTGTATGCTCCCAGCTGGC. +. FFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFBFBFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFF<FFFFFBFFFFFFFF<BFFFBFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFBFFFFFFFFFF<FFFFBFFFFFFFFFFB. ```. fastp `version 0.20.0` command:. ```bash. fastp --in1 $1.F.fq.gz --in2 $1.R.fq.gz --out1 $1.R1.fq.gz --out2 $1.R2.fq.gz --cut_front --cut_tail --cut_window_size 5 --cut_mean_quality 15 --correction -q 15 -u 50 -j $1.json -h $1.html --detect_adapter_for_pe &> $1.trim.log. ```. I've ran this for >200 samples, gzipped and not, and the result is the same each time, a completely empty output file. . Here's the output of a single file:. ```. sentence: No reads detected at all.; Good afternoon,. I've been using `fastp` successfully without issue for several months now, but suddenly the program will not process/recognize any reads at all. I have attempted this with both gzipped and uncompressed fastq files with the same results. I even tested this on fastq files that were successfully trimmed with fastp several months ago and it fails. . sentence: No reads detected at all.; Good afternoon,. I've been using `fastp` successfully without issue for several months now, but suddenly the program will not process/recognize any reads at all. I have attempted this with both gzipped and uncompressed fastq files with the same results. I even tested this on fastq files that were successfully trimmed with fastp several months ago and it fails. . File format from `head -4 filename`. ```. @HISEQ:349:C9CG2ANXX:2:1101:1389:1976 1:N:0:TCCTAT. I've ran this for >200 samples, gzipped and not, and the result is the same each time, a completely empty output file. . Here's the output of a single file:. ```. sentence: No reads detected at all.; Good afternoon,. I've been using `fastp` successfully without issue for several months now, but suddenly the program will not process/recognize any reads at all. I have attempted this with both gzipped and uncompressed fastq files with the same results. I even tested this on fastq files that were successfully trimmed with fastp several months ago and it fails. . File format from `head -4 filename`. ```. @HISEQ:349:C9CG2ANXX:2:1101:1389:1976 1:N:0:TCCTAT. sentence: fastp:UMI; I use fastp to process UMI per_read, as follows:. @A00153:435:HNGTVDSXX:1:1101:3712:1000:**GCTGTCA_GTCCTCT** 1:N:0:GAATTCGT+TTATGAGT. But I use Illumina bcl2fastq to process UMI ,as follows:. @A00153:435:HNGTVDSXX:1:1101:3712:1000:**GCTGTCA+GTCCTCT** 1:N:0:GAATTCGT+TTATGAGT. fastp could offer a parameter to chose the “+” 、“_” or others.

sentence: Feature Request: Distribution of Quality Scores; The Q30 and Q20 percentage stats are clearly available in the output, but I haven't been able to find a full distribution of the quality scores in the output. Is it possible to get a full distribution (i.e. counts you could use to build a histogram) or something similar to fully capture how many of each quality score value is found within the files?

sentence: 5' Adapter Trimming; Can I request 5' adapter/primer trimming (forgive me if I missed it in the docs):. e.g. If a primer sequence is AACTGCC:. ```. Before: 5'-aatgaAACTGCCactgggagagagccatcattgatcgtagctg-3'. After: 5'-actgggagagagccatcattgatcgtagctg-3. ```. This, in combination with the regular 3' trimming would be awesome.

sentence: Specify umi_skip for read1/read2 or index1/index2?; Hello,. It would be convenient if there were a way to specify distinct umi_skip values for read1/read2 or index1/index2. This might be achieved in a similar way as trim_front1 and trim_front2 are specified (e.g. umi_skip1 and umi_skip2). Thanks for the fast and useful tool you've produced for the community!

sentence: fastp with --thread option set doesn't use even half cores allotted; Hi - first time user. Thank you for making an easy to install (bioconda) and use library. I've specified `-w 12` yet I see fastp only uses up to 5-6 cores. Is that by design? Generally with other C++ thread-based libraries it will use all the resources you give it. I would like fastp to use as many resources as allowed to run as quickly as it can.
author: OpenGene

sentence: fastp with --thread option set doesn't use even half cores allotted; Hi - first time user. Thank you for making an easy to install (bioconda) and use library. I've specified `-w 12` yet I see fastp only uses up to 5-6 cores. Is that by design? Generally with other C++ thread-based libraries it will use all the resources you give it. I would like fastp to use as many resources as allowed to run as quickly as it can.

author: OpenGene

sentence: feature request: trim_tail only when adapter is detected; Thanks for this wonderful tool. I really like the before/after comparisons. I would like to replace cutdapt with fastp in my workflows. I sometimes use kits that has a 10-bp connector in addition to the Illumina adapter and the sequence of this connector varies. Depending on the fragment size and read length, this connector may or may not be sequenced. I know I have the option of trimming 10bp at 3' of all reads, but that seems like a waste of data if the connector is not even in the read. I would hope for a feature that would allow trimming 10bp at the 3' only when the Illumina adatper is detected. cutadpt deals with this by allowing Ns in the adapter sequences (-a N{10}AGATCGGAAGAGCACACGTCTGAACTCCAGTCA). fastp currently does not allow Ns in the adapter sequence. If you could consider adding this function, it would help me a lot. Thank you very much.
author: OpenGene

sentence: feature request: trim_tail only when adapter is detected; Thanks for this wonderful tool. I really like the before/after comparisons. I would like to replace cutdapt with fastp in my workflows. I sometimes use kits that has a 10-bp connector in addition to the Illumina adapter and the sequence of this connector varies. Depending on the fragment size and read length, this connector may or may not be sequenced. I know I have the option of trimming 10bp at 3' of all reads, but that seems like a waste of data if the connector is not even in the read. I would hope for a feature that would allow trimming 10bp at the 3' only when the Illumina adatper is detected. cutadpt deals with this by allowing Ns in the adapter sequences (-a N{10}AGATCGGAAGAGCACACGTCTGAACTCCAGTCA). fastp currently does not allow Ns in the adapter sequence. If you could consider adding this function, it would help me a lot. Thank you very much.

sentence: [SUGGESTION] Can the "Before" and "After" statistics be side-to-side?; Just started using the tools, so far works, even does some cleaning by itself (have to take a deeper look to make sure it's enough). . The generated reports are decent, but having to scroll through before and after graphs seem cumbersome. Could the windows be put side-to-side? Also like how the graphs can show more info when moused over. Nice touch.

sentence: duplication rate reporting, mismatch; Dear fastp devs,. I have a high duplication rate report which does not make sense according to the graph that is generated. Duplication rate is reported as 87.6% whereas in the graph it gives a duplication rate of 1 of 91%. **How should I interpret this?**. Data from the json:. ```. "filtering_result": {. "passed_filter_reads": 46475992,. "low_quality_reads": 205838,. "too_many_N_reads": 5826,. "too_short_reads": 20906,. "too_long_reads": 0. },. "duplication": {. "rate": 0.876254,. "histogram": [268418,10761,2802,1567,1125,890,783,669,611,506,461,436,406,350,394,346,330,301,325,280,277,277,228,240,251,247,252,227,210,204,27203],. "mean_gc": [0.295962,0.383945,0.438027,0.462227,0.481799,0.480573,0.493627,0.490489,0.492295,0.479819,0.509778,0.491806,0.496977,0.52335,0.51704,0.495036,0.505692,0.50299,0.488989,0.506373,0.504467,0.495448,0.523099,0.533611,0.528896,0.531031,0.495254,0.498886,0.504276,0.496021,0.503588]. },. ```. I ran it with default settings. (RNAseq data)

author: OpenGene

sentence: mismatches allowed in adapter trimming; Dear all. Thanks for making this great tool available. Maybe, I missed it in the documentation but I can't seem to find a description of how many mismatches you allow when trimming adapters. So my question is: If I explicitely specify a set of adapter sequences, what is the similarity criterion that must be fulfilled in order to trim the adapters? Best regards. Hubert

sentence: Option to disable report output; Forgive me if this is already somewhere, but it would be great to have an option not to generate the trimming reports. Currently I tack on ` --json /dev/null --html /dev/null`

sentence: More statistics for reads; Hi. could you add more statistics for reads in your very useful tool? - median read length. - minimal read length & maximal read length (read length range)

author: OpenGene

sentence: Question: rationale duplication detection; Hi,. Thanks for developing fastp - it is does everything and fast! Small question regarding the duplication detection. From the paper on fastp, and if I am understanding correctly, it seems that the first 12bp of read1 and first 32bp of read2 are used for detection of duplicated fragments (PE mode). Would it be possible to clarify the rationale for these values, for example, why is it asymmetric or why 12 and 32 bps? Thanks in advance. Dieter.

author: OpenGene

sentence: Question: does fastp do quality trimming first or adapter trimming first; Hi . I have a question: when used with default options, does Fastp do quality trimming first before adapter trimming or vice-versa? [Based on Figure 1 of this paper](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6129281/figure/bty560-F1/), it looks to me as though quality trimming is done before adapter trimming, but I could be wrong. Thanks in advance.

sentence: No adapter detected for read1; Hello! I am processing single-end samples from the same sequencing run. I am finding that fastp correctly identifies the primer sequence on some replicates, but on others it returns:. ```. Detecting adapter sequence for read1... No adapter detected for read1. ```. What might be causing this behavior? . Thank you! Henry

author: OpenGene

sentence: Plots: y-axis scaling | plot of 3' trimming; Really nice piece of software :+1: . As a sequencing service provider running devices from MiSeq to NovaSeq we deal with quite a lot of fastq files. . Just two tiny suggestions concerning some plots:. - the `quality` plots should scale on y-axis from 0 to 40 for phred33 (at least optionally) as this way it is by far easier to visually detect relevant differences in a set of files. The scaled (y-zoomed) view makes some plots look more dramatical than they are. - the same is valid for `base content` plot: scaling from 0 to 100% (you are using % in the legend so why not using it on the axis as well?) would make plots - put side by side for some samples - better comparable. And it would also be easier to spot issues in a set of files. - maybe an idea: you could create a plot with fractions of trimmed data (polyA,adapter,quality,whatever can be trimmed from 3' end) over the position (cycle number). The different fractions in different colors. In untrimmed data this would be a line slowly raising towards the end of a read where e.g. low quality increases and where adapters are likely to begin. This is a good tool to see how trimming has worked (or not). Especially when we have the "before/after" plots side-by-side in the report. I will include this tool in our standard data processing pipeline :+1:

author: OpenGene

sentence: Plots: y-axis scaling | plot of 3' trimming; Really nice piece of software :+1: . As a sequencing service provider running devices from MiSeq to NovaSeq we deal with quite a lot of fastq files. . Just two tiny suggestions concerning some plots:. - the `quality` plots should scale on y-axis from 0 to 40 for phred33 (at least optionally) as this way it is by far easier to visually detect relevant differences in a set of files. The scaled (y-zoomed) view makes some plots look more dramatical than they are. - the same is valid for `base content` plot: scaling from 0 to 100% (you are using % in the legend so why not using it on the axis as well?) would make plots - put side by side for some samples - better comparable. And it would also be easier to spot issues in a set of files. - maybe an idea: you could create a plot with fractions of trimmed data (polyA,adapter,quality,whatever can be trimmed from 3' end) over the position (cycle number). The different fractions in different colors. In untrimmed data this would be a line slowly raising towards the end of a read where e.g. low quality increases and where adapters are likely to begin. This is a good tool to see how trimming has worked (or not). Especially when we have the "before/after" plots side-by-side in the report. I will include this tool in our standard data processing pipeline :+1:

And it would also be easier to spot issues in a set of files. - maybe an idea: you could create a plot with fractions of trimmed data (polyA,adapter,quality,whatever can be trimmed from 3' end) over the position (cycle number). The different fractions in different colors. In untrimmed data this would be a line slowly raising towards the end of a read where e.g. low quality increases and where adapters are likely to begin. This is a good tool to see how trimming has worked (or not). Especially when we have the "before/after" plots side-by-side in the report. I will include this tool in our standard data processing pipeline :+1:

author: OpenGene

sentence: Adding UMI from third file fails with zero length reads; The procedure linked below fails when the read receiving the UMI from the third file has zero length. This results in read pairs that do not have the same name (when one read of the pair has zero length) and thus failure occurs in BWA MEM. . https://github.com/OpenGene/fastp/issues/23.

It also showed the report, such as Read2 before filtering:. total reads: 99942362. total bases: 14991354300. Q20 bases: 14555040803(97.0896%). Q30 bases: 13883685796(92.6113%). Merged and filtered:. total reads: 10779976. total bases: 2350417499. Q20 bases: 2317218459(98.5875%). Q30 bases: 2252984710(95.8547%). It also showed the report, such as Read2 before filtering:. total reads: 99942362. total bases: 14991354300. Q20 bases: 14555040803(97.0896%). Q30 bases: 13883685796(92.6113%). Merged and filtered:. total reads: 10779976. total bases: 2350417499. Q20 bases: 2317218459(98.5875%). Q30 bases: 2252984710(95.8547%). Filtering result:. reads passed filter: 198439704. reads failed due to low quality: 1333036. reads failed due to too many N: 10212. reads failed due to too short: 101772. reads with adapter trimmed: 2351116. bases trimmed due to adapters: 71760017. reads with polyX in 3' end: 151660. bases trimmed in polyX tail: 2102558. reads corrected by overlap analysis: 1014234. bases corrected by overlap analysis: 2285328. sentence: Feature request: allow multiple files to be input at once; Often sequencing files come in parts, it would be convenient to able to specify a list of files to be read by `-i` or `-I`. Thanks for all your work!

sentence: Undefined option --adapter_fasta; I got this error message when I ran fastp with a adapter file. undefined option: --adapter_fasta. The fastp version is fastp 0.19.7. The conda download page indicated 0.20. but after I conda update, I still got the same version as before. . Which version support the --adapter_fasta? Thanks very much for a terrific tool!
author: OpenGene

sentence: Up to 16 threads?; Actually it uses only 4-6 cores in real datasets no matter how many threads I assigned. Why limiting it to 16 cores only? How can I use 128 threads on my linux server.
author: OpenGene

sentence: Up to 16 threads?; Actually it uses only 4-6 cores in real datasets no matter how many threads I assigned. Why limiting it to 16 cores only? How can I use 128 threads on my linux server.
author: OpenGene

sentence: Feature Request: set order of execution on command line; In some cases the **order** of what has to be trimmed is important. I propose that this should be controlled on the command line. - by the order parameter show up in command line (probably difficult and hard to "see"). - by providing some kind of "sequence", e.g. "quality"=1, "polyA"=2, "adapter"=3 etc. and then as parameter `--order 1,3,2` or something similar.
author: OpenGene

sentence: fastp "Error to read gzip file"; Hi,. I'm trying to run fastp on WES .fastq.gz files but for each of them i get "Error to read gzip file". The code im running is . > cd $WES/input/. > for f in *_R1*; do. > export R1="$(basename "$f")". > export R2=`echo "$(basename "$f")" | sed 's/_R1/_R2/'`. > echo "found" "$R1" "$R2". > done. > echo "input files are" "$R1" "$R2". > . > cd $WES/output. > fastp -i $R1 -o ${R1%%.*}_trimmed.fastq.gz -I $R2 -O ${R2%%.*}_trimmed.fastq.gz --unpaired1 ${R1%%.*}_unpair.fastq --unpaired2 ${R2%%.*}_unpair.fastq --failed_out ${R1%%_*}_failed.fastq -c --detect_adapter_for_pe -h fasp.html --dont_overwrite -z 9 -w 8. I'd really like to use gziped files rather than decomp and raw fastq. Is that an error on my side or else ? fastqc and trimmomatic used these files perfectly fine, but not fastp. P.S. github detects some part of code as BBcodes so dont mind it please
author: OpenGene

The code im running is . > cd $WES/input/. > for f in *_R1*; do. > export R1="$(basename "$f")". > export R2=`echo "$(basename "$f")" | sed 's/_R1/_R2/'`. > echo "found" "$R1" "$R2". > done. > echo "input files are" "$R1" "$R2". > . > cd $WES/output. > fastp -i $R1 -o ${R1%%.*}_trimmed.fastq.gz -I $R2 -O ${R2%%.*}_trimmed.fastq.gz --unpaired1 ${R1%%.*}_unpair.fastq --unpaired2 ${R2%%.*}_unpair.fastq --failed_out ${R1%%_*}_failed.fastq -c --detect_adapter_for_pe -h fasp.html --dont_overwrite -z 9 -w 8. I'd really like to use gziped files rather than decomp and raw fastq. Is that an error on my side or else ? fastqc and trimmomatic used these files perfectly fine, but not fastp. P.S. github detects some part of code as BBcodes so dont mind it please
author: OpenGene

sentence: what if the short read includs adatper in both ends?; Hi Folks,. I would like to know if the adapters are included in both ends of reads, due to the short insert (100 bp) during library construction. the Hiseq PE-150 was used for sequencing. How does the fastp remove the adapter in the other end? . Thanks. Best

sentence: does polyG get trimmed only if it's at the 3' end of read?; First thanks for writing such a wonderful tool! Quick question, if there is a stretch of polyG in the middle of reads, does it get trimmed? Or only polyG at the 3' (meaning all bases after the polyG are Gs) of reads get trimmed? . Thanks! Dan.
author: OpenGene

sentence: Complexity filter; Hello ,. I have just used fastp on severlal fastq files from metagenomic analysis. It is really fast but after filtering, there a still a considerable number of low complexity reads in the ouput files with large stretches of simple repeats such as :. >1	GTACTGGTGCTATATAATTTTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGCAAGTGGTATCAAACTCACG. >2. CCCCACACATATACATAATTTAAAATAAAATCCCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTC. >3. CTGCTGGTGGTGGTGTTGAGGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTAGGACATTTGCTCCTA. I have used the default value (30%) for filtering. It would be nice to have an additional option which also take those repeats into account when filtering low complexity reads. With best wishes,. Thorsten
author: OpenGene

CCCCACACATATACATAATTTAAAATAAAATCCCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTC. >3. CTGCTGGTGGTGGTGTTGAGGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTGTAGGACATTTGCTCCTA. I have used the default value (30%) for filtering. It would be nice to have an additional option which also take those repeats into account when filtering low complexity reads. With best wishes,. Thorsten

sentence: tag count; Hi,. I like to use FASTP but it appears that it does not support tag count. On the other hand, [preprocess.seq](https://github.com/atulkakrana/preprocess.seq) is able to produce it. Is there a way to create tag count from FASTP results? Thank you in advance,. Michal
author: OpenGene

sentence: Compatible with MGISEQ fastq file; Hi, . As MGISEQ fastq file contain '/1 | /2' at the end of the read ID, after adding UMI information, it will cause an error while mapping with BWA-MEM:. `[mem_sam_pe] [mem_sam_pe] paired reads have different names: "V300041225L2C001R0010000001/1:umi_TTCAC_TTAGA", "V300041225L2C001R0010000001/2:umi_TTCAC_TTAGA"`. How can I deal with this problem ? . Thanks in advance ! Best,. Gerde

sentence: Why is 270 the maximum measurement limit for "Insert size estimation" ??; Hi, . It was very convenient when I used fastp. but, my report says "88.524713% reads are with unknown length". Certainly, since I experimented with a fragmentation size of 350 and 150PE, most reads would be longer than 270bp. Why is 270 the maximum measurement limit for "Insert size estimation" ?? ![newplot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/43412957/71089706-c7688f80-21e4-11ea-9107-132f6c653c85.png).
author: OpenGene

sentence: Bases under quality score remained after trimming (What is the underlying methods for quality trimming?); Hello. I just wondering what is the underlying method for quality trimming (cannot find it from the paper) because I observed several important issues that people might realized. (1) I used this tool (v.0.19.7) with the option of quality score 20 cutoff and 50 length cutoff but default option allowed us to have up to 40% of unqualified reads can be maintained. Therefore, I ended up getting larger dataset compared to Solexaqa but I found many bases are below 20 present in each read. (It might be okay with the assembly but it could be the problem with any type of analysis with short reads especially for SNP analysis...). (2) Then, I set the option of 0 percent of unqualified base and expected to have the same results with solexqa. However, it removes a lot of reads that actually passed the cutoff of phred score 20 and length of 50. (ended up getting ~35% of reads remains after filtering, while ~70% of reads remained with solexaqa).
author: OpenGene

sentence: failed to detect adapter sequences automatically; See https://trace.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Traces/sra/?run=SRR500504 as an example. Obviously the last 18 bases `TCGTATGCCGTCTTCTGC` are something like "adapters" as all the reads have such identical segments! How ever fastp failed to detect and clip such segments.

author: OpenGene

sentence: Why does the report "after filtering" results when no filtering is performed?; I want to run `fastp` for quality control only. I ran . ```. fastp -i MYFILE.fq.gz \. 	--disable_adapter_trimming \. 	--disable_quality_filtering \. 	--disable_length_filtering \. 	--disable_trim_poly_g \. 	-h fastp_res.html. ```. and get `fastp_res.html` which does contain the sections for "after filtering" including the figures. Why are these sections there if no filtering was performed? Also, the runtime compared to . ```. fastp -i MYFILE.fq.gz \. 	--disable_adapter_trimming \. 	-h fastp_res.html. ```. is the same. Does it need to take the same time?
author: OpenGene

sentence: docker运行时同样的环境centos7和alpine:3.10效率差3倍，为什么？; 您好，我想问一下为什么。同一个虚拟机下，docker运行时同样的环境centos7和alpine:3.10环境，效率差3倍.   | centos | alpine. 耗时（duration）| 30m 43s | 1h 46m. 分配的CPU（allocated cpus） | 4 | 4. CPU使用率（%cpu） | 265.1 | 247.5. 内存使用（rss, GB） | 0.3 | 0.3. 同一个命令 fastp -i SRR6750042_R1.fq.gz -I SRR6750042_R2.fq.gz -A -Q -G -w $cpus -h run_SRR6750042_new.html.
author: OpenGene

sentence: PhiX spike-in; Hi,. Thanks for developing fastp! I was wondering if it detects and removes PhiX spike-in by default? Thanks in advance!
author: OpenGene

sentence: PhiX spike-in; Hi,. Thanks for developing fastp! I was wondering if it detects and removes PhiX spike-in by default? Thanks in advance!
author: OpenGene

sentence: [SUGGESTION] Could RX & QX tags be added to FASTQ?; Hi sfchen & fastp team,. Thank you very much for the great tool! It is really convenient and fast! I want to suggest a UMI-tags-adding function. It is very similiar to AnnotateBamWithUmis but different. . My PE data are in three FASTQ files:. R1: Fw read. R2: umi. R3: Re read. I tried AWK to add RX & QX UMI information to read head of R1 and R3 as below. It worked but consumed too many IO operations, RAM, and too much time (fq.gz -> fq -> awk -> gz). . Your "FASTQ with UMI integrated" function in the fastp can take zipped fastq and process fast. Could you make RX/QX-tag-adding as a new funciton in the next version? Thank you so much. . awk -F"[[:space:]]" 'NR==FNR{ if(NR%4==1){head[NR]=$1;next} if(NR%4==2){mbc[NR-1]=$1;next} if(NR%4==0){QX[NR-3]=$1;next};next} {if(head[FNR]==$1){print $0" RX:Z:"mbc[FNR]" QX:Z:"QX[FNR];next} {print $0}}' R2_umi.fastq R1.fastq > R1_RXQX.fastq. (@A00000:00:AAAAAAA:3:1204:2234:4000 1:N:0:GATCGATC RX:Z:ATCGCCTA QX:Z:FFFFFFFF). awk -F"[[:space:]]" 'NR==FNR{ if(NR%4==1){head[NR]=$1;indexes[NR]=$2;next} if(NR%4==2){mbc[NR-1]=$1;next} if(NR%4==0){QX[NR-3]=$1;next};next} {if(head[FNR]==$1){print head[FNR]" "indexes[FNR]" RX:Z:"mbc[FNR]" QX:Z:"QX[FNR];next} {print $0}}' R2_umi.fastq R3.fastq > newR2_RXQX.fastq. (@A00000:00:AAAAAAA:3:1204:2234:4000 2:N:0:GATCGATC RX:Z:ATCGCCTA QX:Z:FFFFFFFF)
author: OpenGene

sentence: How to setup the different filter standard for each reads?; Hi. I want to set up the different standard for each reads. For example，. - **Read length**: If the length of R1 read is <70 or R2 read is <65,the R1/R2 read pair is dropped. or. - **low complexity** :low complexity is ≥0.55 for the R1 read or low complexity ≥0.80 for the R2 read, the read pair is dropped. FASTP seem not to be support for it .
author: OpenGene

sentence: Feature request: more support for streams and pipes; It would be nice to have full functionality when using input streams (for example adapter detection). Along these lines, it would be great to be able to use bash's process substitution or named pipes as input; thereby increasing the flexibility of execution. For example, I would like be able to run:. ```. fastp -i <(zcat 1a.fq.gz 1b.fq.gz) -I <(zcat 2a.fq.gz 2b.fq.gz) ... --detect_adapter_for_pe. ```. Thank you @sfchen for you awesome tool!
author: OpenGene

sentence: Feature request: more support for streams and pipes; It would be nice to have full functionality when using input streams (for example adapter detection). Along these lines, it would be great to be able to use bash's process substitution or named pipes as input; thereby increasing the flexibility of execution. For example, I would like be able to run:. ```. fastp -i <(zcat 1a.fq.gz 1b.fq.gz) -I <(zcat 2a.fq.gz 2b.fq.gz) ... --detect_adapter_for_pe. ```. Thank you @sfchen for you awesome tool!

sentence: quality string length is not equal to sequence length; In order to quality control for my paired-end fastq data, i run the fastp software like this, "fastp -i x_1.fq -I x_2.fq -o fastp_result/x_1.fa -O fastp_result/x_2.fq". And then, the processed fq files were provided into STAR to map. During this step, a error occured "quality string length is not equal to sequence length". So, do you have any suggestions? Thank you

sentence: umi trimming and deduplication; Hi . I used fastp to trim out umi seqeunce by using the option below,. `fastp -i R1_001.fastq.gz -I R2_001.fastq.gz -o R1_001_umi.fastq.gz -OR2_001_umi.fastq.gz -U --umi_loc=per_read --umi_len=4 --umi_skip=1 -g –Q --adapter_sequence=AGATCGGAAGAGCACACGTCTGAACTCCAGTCA --adapter_sequence_r2=AGATCGGAAGAGCGTCGTGTAGGGAAAGAGTGT`. De-duplication step was already done by this command? or do I need other step for de-duplication? Thanks! HJ.

sentence: adapter trimming by overlap analysis; I have just used fastp (thank you) and I have one comment and one question. comment 1:. I saw that a paired-end read attached below were trimmed,. where I used the following parameter:. --adapter_sequence=AGATCGGAAGAGCACACGTCTGAACTCCAGTCA --adapter_sequence_r2=AGATCGGAAGAGCGTCGTGTAGGGAAAGAGTGT -l 50 -y -p. The overlapped sequence is similar but the trimmed sequence is not similar to the input adapter sequence. When I rerun fastp further with --overlap_diff_limit 3 --overlap_diff_percent_limit 10. So I know that I can avoid overtrimming but I think that it seems good that when pairs of reads are overlapped and adapter sequences are specified, the overhanged sequences are not trimmed if they are unsimilar to the input adapter sequences. --input--. @ID1 1:N:0:CTACGACA+GAGTCCAA. TCATATTTTATGTACAGTATATAATGTATAGTTTGGGTACTTTGATATTTTATGTACTCTATAGAATATATATCTGGTGTACTTTGATATATTATGTACAGAATAAAATATATATTTGATGTACTTTCATATTTTATGTACAGTTTATAAT. +. FFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFF:FFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFF:FFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFF. @ID1 2:N:0:CTACGACA+GAGTCCAA. ACATTAAGTACCTAAGTACCCCAAATATATATTTTATACTGTACATGAAATATCAAAGTTCACAAACTATATATTATATACTGTACATAAAATATCAAAGTACCCAAGGTATATATTCTATACTGTACAAAAAATATCAAAGTACCCAAGC. +. FFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFF:FFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFF:FFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFF,FFFFF. --output. @ID1 1:N:0:CTACGACA+GAGTCCAA. TCATATTTTATGTACAGTATATAATGTATAGTTTGGGTACTTTGATATTTTATGTACTCTATAGAATATATATCTGGTGTACTTTGATATATTATGT. +. FFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFF:FFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFF:FFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFF. @ID1 2:N:0:CTACGACA+GAGTCCAA. I saw that a paired-end read attached below were trimmed,. where I used the following parameter:. --adapter_sequence=AGATCGGAAGAGCACACGTCTGAACTCCAGTCA --adapter_sequence_r2=AGATCGGAAGAGCGTCGTGTAGGGAAAGAGTGT -l 50 -y -p. The overlapped sequence is similar but the trimmed sequence is not similar to the input adapter sequence. When I rerun fastp further with --overlap_diff_limit 3 --overlap_diff_percent_limit 10. So I know that I can avoid overtrimming but I think that it seems good that when pairs of reads are overlapped and adapter sequences are specified, the overhanged sequences are not trimmed if they are unsimilar to the input adapter sequences. --input--. @ID1 1:N:0:CTACGACA+GAGTCCAA. TCATATTTTATGTACAGTATATAATGTATAGTTTGGGTACTTTGATATTTTATGTACTCTATAGAATATATATCTGGTGTACTTTGATATATTATGTACAGAATAAAATATATATTTGATGTACTTTCATATTTTATGTACAGTTTATAAT. +. sentence: Trimming Multiple Copies of same adapter.; Hello,. I found a problem sample which has multiple copies of a single adaptor in the same read. fastp identifies the adaptor correctly `AGATCGGAAGAGCACACGTCTGAACTCCAGTCA`. and removed it from the sequence. `AGATCGGAAGAGCACACGAGATCGGAAGAGCACACGTCTGAACTCCAGTCA`. leaving. `AGATCGGAAGAGCACACG`. I can't see a parameter to remove adapters multiple times - could you please advise. Thanks
author: OpenGene

I found a problem sample which has multiple copies of a single adaptor in the same read. fastp identifies the adaptor correctly `AGATCGGAAGAGCACACGTCTGAACTCCAGTCA`. and removed it from the sequence. `AGATCGGAAGAGCACACGAGATCGGAAGAGCACACGTCTGAACTCCAGTCA`. leaving. `AGATCGGAAGAGCACACG`. I can't see a parameter to remove adapters multiple times - could you please advise. Thanks

sentence: Process paired-end + dual-indexed fastq files; Hey,. Great job on a pretty cool fastq processing tool! Would it be easily possible to use fastp to process data that is paired-end with two index reads? So the input would be 4 fastq file paths (read1, read2, index1, index2) and i'd like to trim for adapters in read 1 and read 2. The index reads should be kept in sync with the actual reads (eg if a read gets discarded, discard those index reads too). It would be highly appreciated if you would be able to add such functionality! Thanks and best,. Christoph

sentence: Fastq files with MS-DOS end-line break; Hello,. So I have been running fastp and it has worked previously, but recently I ran a sample where roughly 100K reads out of 1M reads were trimmed and then fastp stops with the message:. ```. ERROR: sequence and quality have different length:. @read name. Read Sequence. +. ```. I did dig a bit in the fastqreader code and it seems that there's some offset by 1 here so that the separator line now is empty and the separator instead occupies the line for quality. I did find that the file has ^M$ at the end of each line indicating the file has been saved on a windows machine. By looking at the getline function in the fastqreader it seems you tried to deal with this, but it seems the problem has persisted.
author: OpenGene

sentence: ab-initio adapter detection - incorrect adapter classification; Dear developers,. When I check our RNAseq (we're expecting the: Illumina TruSeq Adapters for Read 1 and Read 2) data for adapters, fastp detects a mix of the correct Adapters but sometimes also the following adapters: Nextera_LMP_Read1_External_Adapter/Nextera_LMP_Read2_External_Adapter . The difference between the Illumina Truseq and Nextera LMP Adapters is exactly 1 A at the beginning of the adapter sequence that is missing in the Nextera ones. . The easiest solution is removing the LMP adapters from the list, since the protocol is not used anymore. But it may also be a bug... Best regards,. Christopher Previti.

The difference between the Illumina Truseq and Nextera LMP Adapters is exactly 1 A at the beginning of the adapter sequence that is missing in the Nextera ones. . The easiest solution is removing the LMP adapters from the list, since the protocol is not used anymore. But it may also be a bug... Best regards,. Christopher Previti.
author: OpenGene

sentence: `--trim_poly_x` like function from 5'; It would be nice to have a `--trim_poly_x` like function which trims from the 5' site. We are trying some single-cell protocols which sometimes have a polyA 5' tail in one of the reads.

sentence: Add test for input filename = output filename (-i is equal to -o) ; fastp will overwrite -o without checking if it is the same as -i. Worth adding a check for this scenario.

sentence: Best practice for preprocessing Nanopore reads; First of all, congratulations on that fantastic tool for its speed. . I am not sure if "fastp" automatically detects adapters used by ONT libraries. And what would be the recommended flags to treat this kind of reads obtained by ONT?

sentence: undefined short option: -; Hello. I'm trying to remove the first 14 bases of my sequencing read, by running this command:. fastp -i ~/stress_mirna/AH1-R1-trimmed.fastq -5, --cut_front cut_front_window_size 14 cut_front_mean_quality 30 -o ~/stress_mirna/AH1-R1-trimmed2.fastq. But I receive the error message. undefined short option: -. Could you please tell me what wrong I'm doing here?
author: OpenGene

sentence: Removing poly-A tail; Hello. I have done paired-end sequencing and need to remove poly-A and poly-T sequences from R1 and R2 reads. Based on the manual, I ran this command:. fastp -x -i AH1_R1.fastq -I AH1_R2.fastq -o AH1-R1-trimmed.fastq -O AH1-R2-trimmed.fastq. I also tried --trim_poly_x option, but it seems that the sequences are not removed, as the base content plot after filtering for read1 still shows an excess of A (44%). Could you please tell me what I should do to fix the problem? Thank you
author: OpenGene

sentence: Repurposing 10x Chromium Whole Genome Data-Removing adapter and barcode; This may be a goofy question but we recently sequenced and organism using a 10x whole genome strategy. We pulled out a bacterial endosymbiont genome and in subsequent PacBio sequencing we got a really nice circular chromosome. I would like to repurpose the 10x data to be able to polish the PacBio generated endosymbiont genome. What strategy would be best to remove both the adapter AND the barcode from the reads?
author: OpenGene

sentence: --adapter_sequence specifies multiple adapter sequences; Hi dear team ,. fastp is power tools for NGS data QC，i use the --detect_adapter_for_pe parameter for my PE data,but the adapter not be trim from my data view by fastqc,so i am going to use --adapter_sequence specifies adapter sequences,but i am confuse that if i want to specifies multiple adapter sequences,how could i give this parameter,just like i ant to trim adapter TGTGTATAAGAGACAG and AGATGTGTATAAGAGACAG from R1 data,and trim the same adapter sequences for R2 data ,Looking forward to your reply,thanks!

sentence: adapters not removed - mismatches insertion/deletion ; Hello,. I used this option --detect_adapter_for_pe to remove adapters but some adapters were still there in my contigs after assembly. I noticed mismatches that are insertion/deletion in the adapters I am wondering if fastp can recognize mismatches that are insertion/deletion and detect adapters with one deletion? Here is my command line:. ./fastp --in1 JC-0001_S929_L001_R1_001.fastq.gz --in2 JC-0001_S929_L001_R2_001.fastq.gz --out1 JC-0001_S929_L001_R1_001.cleaned.fastq.gz --out2 JC-0001_S929_L001_R2_001.clened.fastq.gz --correction --cut_front --cut_tail --detect_adapter_for_pe. Best regards,. Marilyne
author: OpenGene

I noticed mismatches that are insertion/deletion in the adapters I am wondering if fastp can recognize mismatches that are insertion/deletion and detect adapters with one deletion? Here is my command line:. ./fastp --in1 JC-0001_S929_L001_R1_001.fastq.gz --in2 JC-0001_S929_L001_R2_001.fastq.gz --out1 JC-0001_S929_L001_R1_001.cleaned.fastq.gz --out2 JC-0001_S929_L001_R2_001.clened.fastq.gz --correction --cut_front --cut_tail --detect_adapter_for_pe. Best regards,. Marilyne

author: OpenGene

sentence: Option `--trim_poly_g` would benefit from logging/reporting information; At first I though this option was being ignored because there's no indication that it's actually doing anything in the summary outputs. This in contrast to the poly-X trimmer which reports the number of reads trimmed, number of bases trimmed, etc. It would be a nice touch to have the same information reported for the poly-G trimmer. Especially since this option will operate prior to the poly-X trimmer if both options are given.
author: OpenGene

sentence: other adapter sequences?; Hi there, . I have an Illumina PE rna-seq data which adapters have not been detected by fastQC nor fastp. Looks like the adapters have been removed already. However the fastp reports there were 3374 other adapter sequences in read1 and 4202 other adapter sequences in read2. Is there any way to check these sequences out? Thanks in advance.

author: OpenGene

sentence: Early termination after 5 million read pairs have been processed.; Hello! I've been using `fastp` to process FASTQs found here: https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ena/data/view/SRR8980191. When I run the command:. ```. fastp -i SRR8980191-Adult-Mouse-Brain-seq_Mus_musculus_RNA-Seq_1.fastq.gz -I SRR8980191-Adult-Mouse-Brain-seq_Mus_musculus_RNA-Seq_2.fastq.gz -o R1_trimmed.fq.gz -O R2_trimmed.fq.gz -h fastp.html -j fastp.json -V. ```. I get output:. ```. [16:30:45] start to load data. [16:30:58] loaded 1M read pairs. [16:31:10] loaded 2M read pairs. [16:31:23] loaded 3M read pairs. [16:31:36] loaded 4M read pairs. [16:31:47] loaded 5M read pairs. Terminated. ```. And while `R1_trimmed.fq.gz` and `R2_trimmed.fq.gz` are produced, they're way smaller than I would expect, and no `fastp.html` nor `fastp.json` files are produced. I've run it a few times and used different versions of `fastp` (0.20.1, which terminates after 4M read pairs; 0.20.0, which terminates after 5M read pairs; 0.19.3, which terminates after 1M read pairs). I'm pretty certain my files have about 140 million reads, obtained by running. ```. zcat SRR8980191-Adult-Mouse-Brain-seq_Mus_musculus_RNA-Seq_1.fastq.gz | wc -l. ```. And dividing by 4. Whatever it is, it's certainly far more than 5 million. Any idea what might be happening? I should have plenty of memory and I have plenty of storage. Thank you so much!

author: OpenGene

sentence: Question about duplication level; Hi,. I first time handling the fastq files so I used fastp for the preprocessing of one of the paired-end data. This software is super fast. Thanks for building this. I received 18.64% duplicated reads, I am wondering if this software removes all duplicates? Another question is that is there a duplication level that is not acceptable e.g. indicates the sample is poor?

sentence: Clarification de novo PE adapter detection; I am a bit uncertain about how to interpret the article with respect to PE de novo adapter detection. . From the paper I interpret that. 1. overlap-based PE adapter detection does not make any assumption about the R1 and R2 adapters, except that they are of identical lengths (if the reads are of identical lengths), and . 2. that the overlap-based PE adapter detection (if turned on) has priority over the known-adapter detection such that the latter will only be done, if the former fails. Is this correct? If so, this would mean that with overlap-based detection active there is no guarantee about the cut adapter sequences. E.g.:. * There could be multiple R1 sequences. There could be multiple R2 sequences. No grouping, clustering, etc. is done to check whether a consensus actually exists. * R1 and R2 may have widely different sequences. Whether these cases actually occur with data is not clear to me yet -- also not whether this actually is a problem for the follow-up analysis. It's probably only relevant for some datasets, but it would be good to know whether my considerations are correct. I'd appreciate any comment on this. If my considerations are correct maybe it would be worth mentioning this behavior somewhere in the documentation.

sentence: Clarification de novo PE adapter detection; I am a bit uncertain about how to interpret the article with respect to PE de novo adapter detection. . From the paper I interpret that. 1. overlap-based PE adapter detection does not make any assumption about the R1 and R2 adapters, except that they are of identical lengths (if the reads are of identical lengths), and . 2. that the overlap-based PE adapter detection (if turned on) has priority over the known-adapter detection such that the latter will only be done, if the former fails. Is this correct? If so, this would mean that with overlap-based detection active there is no guarantee about the cut adapter sequences. E.g.:. * There could be multiple R1 sequences. There could be multiple R2 sequences. No grouping, clustering, etc. is done to check whether a consensus actually exists. * R1 and R2 may have widely different sequences. Whether these cases actually occur with data is not clear to me yet -- also not whether this actually is a problem for the follow-up analysis. It's probably only relevant for some datasets, but it would be good to know whether my considerations are correct. I'd appreciate any comment on this. If my considerations are correct maybe it would be worth mentioning this behavior somewhere in the documentation.

sentence: UMI; If I use "--umi --umi_loc=read1 --umi_len=6" , does fastp simply remove the first 6 bases from the start of each read and append it to the read names? Can fastp then do dedup as UMI-tools does?

author: OpenGene

sentence: Feature Request - report adapter names detected/removed; You implemented two adapter removal processes (by overlap analysis and by adapter sequence), so thank you for all your efforts! I don't know of another read filtering package that reports the adapter names removed, but I think it would be valuable to log for routine work as a confirmation the . **(1)** correct adapters were removed and . **(2)** off-target adapters were not removed. This might not be an easy addition for reporting the overlap analysis searches, but I think it could be done with the by adapter sequence searches. You already store a std::map object of the sequences and their names. **Current output:**. ```. reads with adapter trimmed: 184542. bases trimmed due to adapters: 2575728. ```. **Example of ideal output:**. ```. reads with adapter trimmed: 184542. bases trimmed due to adapters: 2575728. adapters detected: 184542. TruSeq_Adapter_Index_25: 184532. I7_Primer_Nextera_XT_Index_Kit_v2_N720: 10. ```. The HTML report currently just lists "other adapter sequences \<int>" for R1 and R2, and could be expanded in a similar naming way as the output printed. As folks suggest options to change how adapters are detected (e.g., #256, #200, and #130), I think this will become more important.
author: OpenGene

This might not be an easy addition for reporting the overlap analysis searches, but I think it could be done with the by adapter sequence searches. You already store a std::map object of the sequences and their names. **Current output:**. ```. reads with adapter trimmed: 184542. bases trimmed due to adapters: 2575728. ```. **Example of ideal output:**. ```. reads with adapter trimmed: 184542. bases trimmed due to adapters: 2575728. adapters detected: 184542. TruSeq_Adapter_Index_25: 184532. I7_Primer_Nextera_XT_Index_Kit_v2_N720: 10. ```. The HTML report currently just lists "other adapter sequences \<int>" for R1 and R2, and could be expanded in a similar naming way as the output printed. As folks suggest options to change how adapters are detected (e.g., #256, #200, and #130), I think this will become more important.
author: OpenGene

TruSeq_Adapter_Index_25: 184532. I7_Primer_Nextera_XT_Index_Kit_v2_N720: 10. ```. The HTML report currently just lists "other adapter sequences \<int>" for R1 and R2, and could be expanded in a similar naming way as the output printed. As folks suggest options to change how adapters are detected (e.g., #256, #200, and #130), I think this will become more important.

author: OpenGene

sentence: add adapters sequences from BGI/MGI sequencing data to built-in adapters; Hi. I noticed that on the SEQanswers forum a document from BGI has been posted that lists all sequences for the oligos and primers used for BGISEQ/DNBSEQ/MGISEQ library preparation. See [here](http://seqanswers.com/forums/showthread.php?t=87647) for the thread (2nd post). On page 7:. ```. The following sequences are used to filter the adapter contamination in raw data. Forward filter: AAGTCGGAGGCCAAGCGGTCTTAGGAAGACAA. Reverse filter: AAGTCGGATCGTAGCCATGTCGTTCTGTGAGCCAAGGAGTTG. ```. Could these 2 (or maybe all listed) sequences be added to the set of built-in adapters `fastp` uses? Thanks,. Guido
author: OpenGene

See [here](http://seqanswers.com/forums/showthread.php?t=87647) for the thread (2nd post). On page 7:. ```. The following sequences are used to filter the adapter contamination in raw data. Forward filter: AAGTCGGAGGCCAAGCGGTCTTAGGAAGACAA. Reverse filter: AAGTCGGATCGTAGCCATGTCGTTCTGTGAGCCAAGGAGTTG. ```. Could these 2 (or maybe all listed) sequences be added to the set of built-in adapters `fastp` uses? Thanks,. Guido
author: OpenGene

author: OpenGene

sentence: [Feature request] Process a part of reads only; Hi， . In some case, we want to process only a part of reads instead of the whole reads in fastq file, such as the top 1000000 reads of each fastq file, this cant help us to quickly get an overview of the reads quality , and this can also be used as an datasize controller of reads which used in downstream analysis. Thanks a lot! Best,. Gerde

sentence: There is a bug in multiple thread function !!!; The clean fastq's reads count can't repeat after triming if using thread greater than 1. So I think there may be a bug in multiple thread function. I have checked the source code in peprocessor.cpp, but got nothing. Please help me to fix this bug. Thanks.
author: OpenGene

sentence: Segmentation fault error; Hello team! I am currently trying to use the following `fastp` command inside a Docker container for UMI processing:. ```. fastp -i input_1.fastq.gz -I input_2.fastq.gz -o output_1.fastq.gz -O output_2.fastq.gz -U --umi_loc=read2 --umi_len=9 -u 100 -Y 100 -G -Q -A -L -w 1 -n 9. ```. But, I keep getting a Segmentation Fault error no matter what I try. However, this command works perfectly fine when I try to run it locally (Mac laptop). Also, this is the Docker command I'm running in the Dockerfile to install `fastp` inside the Docker container:. ```. ... # Install fastp. RUN cd /tmp \. && wget https://github.com/OpenGene/fastp/archive/v0.20.1.tar.gz \. && tar xf v0.20.1.tar.gz \. && cd fastp-0.20.1 \. && make \. && make install \. && fastp \. && echo "Done installing fastp". ... ```. Please advise if this issue is pointing towards a permissions issue, or some sort of memory issue? (Possibly insufficient memory?)

author: OpenGene

sentence: No warning for truncated fastq.gz file; Hi. I use fastp 0.19.5 on Linux and have an issue with truncated fastq.gz files. Sometimes downloaded fastq.gz files are incomplete, truncated and fastp processes them as if they were complete. For paired-end reads truncation implies that both fastq files have different numbers of reads. On a truncated fastq.gz file the _zcat_ command returns something like:. ```. $ zcat SRRaaa_1.fastq.gz >/dev/null. gzip: SRRaaa_1.fastq.gz: invalid compressed data--crc error. gzip: SRRaaa_1.fastq.gz: invalid compressed data--length error. ```. Here is my command:. `fastp -i SRRaaa_1.fastq.gz -I SRRaaa_2.fastq.gz --json SRRaaa.fastp.json --html SRRaaa.fastp.html --thread 2 > SRRaaa.fastp.log 2>&1`
author: OpenGene

sentence: No warning for truncated fastq.gz file; Hi. I use fastp 0.19.5 on Linux and have an issue with truncated fastq.gz files. Sometimes downloaded fastq.gz files are incomplete, truncated and fastp processes them as if they were complete. For paired-end reads truncation implies that both fastq files have different numbers of reads. On a truncated fastq.gz file the _zcat_ command returns something like:. ```. $ zcat SRRaaa_1.fastq.gz >/dev/null. gzip: SRRaaa_1.fastq.gz: invalid compressed data--crc error. gzip: SRRaaa_1.fastq.gz: invalid compressed data--length error. ```. Here is my command:. `fastp -i SRRaaa_1.fastq.gz -I SRRaaa_2.fastq.gz --json SRRaaa.fastp.json --html SRRaaa.fastp.html --thread 2 > SRRaaa.fastp.log 2>&1`
author: OpenGene

sentence: multithreading not working way faster; Hi,. I just run these two commands:. fastp -l 80 -n 3 -w 2 -i fastqdata/file_R1.fastq.gz -I fastqdata/file_R2.fastq.gz -o fastp_output/file_R1_2w.gz -O fastp_output/file_R2_16w.fastp_2w.gz. fastp -l 80 -n 3 -w 16 -i fastqdata/file_R1.fastq.gz -I fastqdata/file_R2.fastq.gz -o fastp_output/file_R1_16w.gz -O fastp_outputfile_R2_16w.fastp_16w.gz. And the execution times were:. * w = 2: 1926 seconds. * w = 16: 2185 seconds (first run), 1558 seconds (second run). Is this somehow expected? Server information:. CORES: 56. RAM: 380 GB. FILES SIZE: 15GB
author: OpenGene

sentence: Insert size peak 35 bp; I have several metagenomes that were sequenced the same way (same Illumina platform, same adapters). Some of them are showing an insert size peak of 35 bp. I have tried providing adapter sequences manually in case they were not being trimmed but this peak size remains the same. What might be causing this peak? Has anyone else experienced this issue?

sentence: Feature Request: Filter polyX; We use NovaSeq to sequencing and have polyG problem. Now we want to remove all reads in 2 paired-end files which has polyG length larger than such as 50 bases.
author: OpenGene

sentence: Adapter cutting metrics not output for single end reads when an adapters FASTA is used; I have observed that giving an adapter FASTA removes the `adapter_cutting` section from the output. I'd like to know which adapter(s) were used in trimming. ~Similarly if I auto-detect~. Here's a simple test case to reproduce:. ```. $ fastp --version. fastp 0.20.1. $ cat in.fastq . @readname. TNGGAGCTGTTTATACTATAATCAAATACACTGTAGGCACCATCAATAGAT. +. ###################################################. $ cat adapters.fasta . >some_adapter. CTGTAGGCACCATCAAT. $$ fastp --in1 in.fastq --out1 out.fastq --json out.json --adapter_fasta adapters.fasta. Detecting adapter sequence for read1... No adapter detected for read1. Read1 before filtering:. total reads: 1. total bases: 51. Q20 bases: 0(0%). Q30 bases: 0(0%). Read1 after filtering:. total reads: 0. total bases: 0. Q20 bases: 0(-nan%). Q30 bases: 0(-nan%). Filtering result:. reads passed filter: 0. reads failed due to low quality: 1. reads failed due to too many N: 0. reads failed due to too short: 0. reads with adapter trimmed: 1. bases trimmed due to adapters: 21. Duplication rate (may be overestimated since this is SE data): 0%. JSON report: out.json. HTML report: fastp.html. fastp --in1 in.fastq --out1 out.fastq --json out.json --adapter_fasta adapters.fasta . fastp v0.20.1, time used: 0 seconds. $ grep adapter_cutting out.json . $ echo $? 1. ```. So the output reports we trimmed the read but no JSON output of which adapter was used. But then if I run it specifying a single adapter, we get a report:. ```. $ fastp --in1 in.fastq --out1 out.fastq --json out.json -a CTGTAGGCACCATCAAT. $ grep adapter_cutting out.json . 	"adapter_cutting": {. ```
author: OpenGene

I'd like to know which adapter(s) were used in trimming. ~Similarly if I auto-detect~. Here's a simple test case to reproduce:. ```. $ fastp --version. fastp 0.20.1. $ cat in.fastq . @readname. TNGGAGCTGTTTATACTATAATCAAATACACTGTAGGCACCATCAATAGAT. +. ###################################################. $ cat adapters.fasta . >some_adapter. CTGTAGGCACCATCAAT. $$ fastp --in1 in.fastq --out1 out.fastq --json out.json --adapter_fasta adapters.fasta. Detecting adapter sequence for read1... No adapter detected for read1. Read1 before filtering:. total reads: 1. total bases: 51. Q20 bases: 0(0%). Q30 bases: 0(0%). Read1 after filtering:. total reads: 0. total bases: 0. Q20 bases: 0(-nan%). Q30 bases: 0(-nan%). Filtering result:. reads passed filter: 0. reads failed due to low quality: 1. reads failed due to too many N: 0. reads failed due to too short: 0. reads with adapter trimmed: 1. bases trimmed due to adapters: 21. Duplication rate (may be overestimated since this is SE data): 0%. JSON report: out.json. HTML report: fastp.html. fastp --in1 in.fastq --out1 out.fastq --json out.json --adapter_fasta adapters.fasta . fastp v0.20.1, time used: 0 seconds. $ grep adapter_cutting out.json . $ echo $? 1. ```. So the output reports we trimmed the read but no JSON output of which adapter was used. But then if I run it specifying a single adapter, we get a report:. ```. $ fastp --in1 in.fastq --out1 out.fastq --json out.json -a CTGTAGGCACCATCAAT. $ grep adapter_cutting out.json . 	"adapter_cutting": {. ```

author: OpenGene

sentence: trimming reads with mixed indices; Hi there,. I am looking a tool just like fastp and want a trimmer that detects the adapter sequence and then trims it off. In some of my libraries there are mixed indices where a single fastq file with have a combination of 6bp index sequences part way into the adapter. I tried running fastp on these data and no errors were thrown, but I also don't see anything suggesting that the trimming was successful or not. . Should I expect fastp to be able to trim the reads of a fastq where there is more than 1 index used in the in the library? If so, is there a way to have fastp report the detected adapter/index combinations? thanks. Richard.

sentence: trimming reads with mixed indices; Hi there,. I am looking a tool just like fastp and want a trimmer that detects the adapter sequence and then trims it off. In some of my libraries there are mixed indices where a single fastq file with have a combination of 6bp index sequences part way into the adapter. I tried running fastp on these data and no errors were thrown, but I also don't see anything suggesting that the trimming was successful or not. . Should I expect fastp to be able to trim the reads of a fastq where there is more than 1 index used in the in the library? If so, is there a way to have fastp report the detected adapter/index combinations? thanks. Richard.

sentence: duplication calculate method; dear fastp support:. we have review the fastp code for duplication method，there is a bit misunderstand is the addRecord function：. `void Duplicate::addRecord(uint64 key, uint64 kmer32, uint8 gc) {. if(mCounts[key] == 0) {. mCounts[key] = 1;. mDups[key] = kmer32;. mGC[key] = gc;. } else {. //printf("%s\t%s\n",mDups[key],kmer32);. if(mDups[key] == kmer32). mCounts[key]++;. else if(mDups[key] > kmer32) {. mDups[key] = kmer32;. mCounts[key] = 1;. mGC[key] = gc;. }. }. }. `. why we choose recount the reads by mDups[key] > kmer32？. In our data，there're several reads have same read1 but different read2，then the duplicate may cause some errors. thankyou！.

sentence: Rename --polyX --> --trim_poly_x in README; Hello,. Thanks again for making this package! It's my favorite read trimmer and merger. I made the mistake of not fully reading the help text and just copy/pasted from the documentation and ran into some errors (https://github.com/czbiohub/nf-predictorthologs/pull/60). Turns out the flag to turn on polyX trimming is `--trim_poly_x` not `--polyX` so this PR fixes that. Thanks! Olga

sentence: Insert size peak ; Hi. I used fastp to trim my ChIP-seq reads. My samples are paired-end reads. After trimming, the report states that. Insert size peak (evaluated by paired-end reads): 0. Is this normal? What is the meaning of insert size peak here?
author: OpenGene

sentence: Insert size peak ; Hi. I used fastp to trim my ChIP-seq reads. My samples are paired-end reads. After trimming, the report states that. Insert size peak (evaluated by paired-end reads): 0. Is this normal? What is the meaning of insert size peak here?
author: OpenGene

sentence: Adapter related options; Hi, I found the adapter related options are confusing and give surprising result as show below. In a word: More adapter information may miss rescue some reads! By the way, fastp v0.21.0 is used. * < Using three adapter related options >. /nfs2/software/fastp/fastp -i t1000.R1.fq -I t1000.R2.fq -o t1000.R1.clean.fq -O t1000.R2.clean.fq --adapter_sequence CTGTCTCTTATACACATCTCCGAGCCCACGAGAC --adapter_sequence_r2 CTGTCTCTTATACACATCTGACGCTGCCGACGA --adapter_fasta adapters.fasta . Filtering result:. reads passed filter: 1274. reads failed due to low quality: 728. reads failed due to too many N: 0. reads failed due to too short: 0. reads with adapter trimmed: 919. * <Using only two adapter related options, without using the --adapter_fasta option>. /nfs2/software/fastp/fastp -i t1000.R1.fq -I t1000.R2.fq -o t1000.R1.clean.fq -O t1000.R2.clean.fq --adapter_sequence CTGTCTCTTATACACATCTCCGAGCCCACGAGAC --adapter_sequence_r2 CTGTCTCTTATACACATCTGACGCTGCCGACGA. Filtering result:. reads passed filter: 1272 ???<1274. reads failed due to low quality: 730. reads failed due to too many N: 0. reads failed due to too short: 0. reads with adapter trimmed: 807. content of adapters.fasta. >commonseq2_in_read1. Filtering result:. reads passed filter: 1274. reads failed due to low quality: 728. reads failed due to too many N: 0. reads failed due to too short: 0. reads with adapter trimmed: 919. * <Using only two adapter related options, without using the --adapter_fasta option>. /nfs2/software/fastp/fastp -i t1000.R1.fq -I t1000.R2.fq -o t1000.R1.clean.fq -O t1000.R2.clean.fq --adapter_sequence CTGTCTCTTATACACATCTCCGAGCCCACGAGAC --adapter_sequence_r2 CTGTCTCTTATACACATCTGACGCTGCCGACGA. Filtering result:. reads passed filter: 1272 ???<1274. reads failed due to low quality: 730. reads failed due to too many N: 0. reads failed due to too short: 0. reads with adapter trimmed: 807. content of adapters.fasta. >commonseq2_in_read1. AGGACTCCAAT. >commonseq1_in_read2. CAAAACGCAATACTGTACATT. Based on Results, we could find that the added 'adapters.fasta' helps to rescue some reads ! So, why would this happen? I think more descriptions are needed for using these options properly. With Best Regards!

Filtering result:. reads passed filter: 1274. reads failed due to low quality: 728. reads failed due to too many N: 0. reads failed due to too short: 0. reads with adapter trimmed: 919. * <Using only two adapter related options, without using the --adapter_fasta option>. /nfs2/software/fastp/fastp -i t1000.R1.fq -I t1000.R2.fq -o t1000.R1.clean.fq -O t1000.R2.clean.fq --adapter_sequence CTGTCTCTTATACACATCTCCGAGCCCACGAGAC --adapter_sequence_r2 CTGTCTCTTATACACATCTGACGCTGCCGACGA. Filtering result:. reads passed filter: 1272 ???<1274. reads failed due to low quality: 730. reads failed due to too many N: 0. reads failed due to too short: 0. reads with adapter trimmed: 807. content of adapters.fasta. >commonseq2_in_read1. AGGACTCCAAT. >commonseq1_in_read2. CAAAACGCAATACTGTACATT. Based on Results, we could find that the added 'adapters.fasta' helps to rescue some reads ! So, why would this happen? I think more descriptions are needed for using these options properly. With Best Regards!

sentence: Error with barcode sequence with NNNN characters; Dear fastp developers/users. I am using fastq for adapter trimming and reads filtering. I know the sequence adapters for both R1 and R2 and my command line as follow: . fastp \. --in1 MAL-R-2_S3_l1l2_R1.fastq \. --in2 MAL-R-2_S3_l1l2_R2.fastq \. --out1 MAL-R-2_S3_l1l2_fastp_R1.fastq \. --out2 MAL-R-2_S3_l1l2_fastp_R2.fastq \. --adapter_sequence=AGATCGGAAGAGCACACGTCTGAACTCCAGTCACNNNNNNATCTCGTATGCCGTCTTCTGCTTG \. --adapter_sequence_r2=AGATCGGAAGAGCGTCGTGTAGGGAAAGAGTGTAGATCTCGGTGGTCGCCGTATCATT \. -q 20 \. -l 25 \. --trim_poly_g \. --trim_poly_x . . I get this error :. ERROR: the adapter <adapter_sequence> can only have bases in {A, T, C, G}, but the given sequence is: AGATCGGAAGAG. CACACGTCTGAACTCCAGTCACNNNNNNATCTCGTATGCCGTCTTCTGCTTG. Please How this could be solved ? Cutadapt accepts these adapters without any error message. . Thank you in advance! Dieunel.
author: OpenGene

I know the sequence adapters for both R1 and R2 and my command line as follow: . fastp \. --in1 MAL-R-2_S3_l1l2_R1.fastq \. --in2 MAL-R-2_S3_l1l2_R2.fastq \. --out1 MAL-R-2_S3_l1l2_fastp_R1.fastq \. --out2 MAL-R-2_S3_l1l2_fastp_R2.fastq \. --adapter_sequence=AGATCGGAAGAGCACACGTCTGAACTCCAGTCACNNNNNNATCTCGTATGCCGTCTTCTGCTTG \. --adapter_sequence_r2=AGATCGGAAGAGCGTCGTGTAGGGAAAGAGTGTAGATCTCGGTGGTCGCCGTATCATT \. -q 20 \. -l 25 \. --trim_poly_g \. --trim_poly_x . . I get this error :. ERROR: the adapter <adapter_sequence> can only have bases in {A, T, C, G}, but the given sequence is: AGATCGGAAGAG. CACACGTCTGAACTCCAGTCACNNNNNNATCTCGTATGCCGTCTTCTGCTTG. Please How this could be solved ? Cutadapt accepts these adapters without any error message. . Thank you in advance! Dieunel.

I know the sequence adapters for both R1 and R2 and my command line as follow: . fastp \. --in1 MAL-R-2_S3_l1l2_R1.fastq \. --in2 MAL-R-2_S3_l1l2_R2.fastq \. --out1 MAL-R-2_S3_l1l2_fastp_R1.fastq \. --out2 MAL-R-2_S3_l1l2_fastp_R2.fastq \. --adapter_sequence=AGATCGGAAGAGCACACGTCTGAACTCCAGTCACNNNNNNATCTCGTATGCCGTCTTCTGCTTG \. --adapter_sequence_r2=AGATCGGAAGAGCGTCGTGTAGGGAAAGAGTGTAGATCTCGGTGGTCGCCGTATCATT \. -q 20 \. -l 25 \. --trim_poly_g \. --trim_poly_x . . I get this error :. ERROR: the adapter <adapter_sequence> can only have bases in {A, T, C, G}, but the given sequence is: AGATCGGAAGAG. CACACGTCTGAACTCCAGTCACNNNNNNATCTCGTATGCCGTCTTCTGCTTG. Please How this could be solved ? Cutadapt accepts these adapters without any error message. . Thank you in advance! Dieunel.

sentence: Why does Adapter Trimmer check all adapter fasta sequences (even after a match is found?); https://github.com/OpenGene/fastp/blob/911533d5275641c7562fe8e236efa33f6bb5d0c8/src/adaptertrimmer.cpp#L58. To save runtime, shouldn't the loop break when a match is found? Also, if there are multiple matching adapter fasta sequences, the adapter counts would become incorrect, wouldn't they? ```. "adapter_cutting": {. "adapter_trimmed_reads": 92945,. "adapter_trimmed_bases": 2348358,. "read1_adapter_sequence": "unspecified",. "read2_adapter_sequence": "unspecified",. "read1_adapter_counts": {"A":838, "AG":826, "AGA":822, "AGATC":853, "AGATCG":859, "AGATCGG":807, "AGATCGGA":778, "AGTTGTGC":1028, "ATCATGCG":972, "ATCGTCTC":1294, "ATCGTGGT":912, "CACACATC":1391, "CCAACGAA":946, "CCTTGGAA":1146, "CGTCTTCA":782, "CTCCTAGT":3934, "CTCTGGAT":2416, "CTGAACGT":1554, "CTTCCTTC":4332, "CTTCGCAA":2072, "GTCAACAG":1619, "GTCCTAAG":1038, "GTCTGCAA":1251, "AGATCGGAA":813, "AGATCGGAAG":807, "AGATCGGAAGA":812, "AGATCGGAAGAG":761, "AGATCGGAAGAGC":779, "AGATCGGAAGAGCA":766, "AGATCGGAAGAGCAC":769, "AGATCGGAAGAGCACACGTCTGAACTCCAGTCACAGAGTAG":886, "others":37137},. "read2_adapter_counts": {"A":844, "AG":828, "AGA":826, "AGATC":852, "AGATCG":867, "AGATCGG":797, "AGATCGGA":774, "AGTTGTGC":1076, "ATCATGCG":1029, "ATCGTCTC":1307, "ATCGTGGT":939, "CACACATC":1536, "CCAACGAA":999, "CCTTGGAA":1118, "CGTCTTCA":895, "CTCCTAGT":3387, "CTCTGGAT":2508, "CTGAACGT":1602, "CTTCCTTC":3355, "CTTCGCAA":2100, "GTCAACAG":1649, "GTCCTAAG":1137, "GTCTGCAA":1259, "AGATCGGAA":830, "AGATCGGAAG":820, "AGATCGGAAGA":830, "AGATCGGAAGAG":763, "AGATCGGAAGAGC":795, "AGATCGGAAGAGCG":778, "AGATCGGAAGAGCGT":765, "others":38604}. },. ```. These are results I've gotten (i.e. the sum of the read1_adapter_counts and read2_adapter_counts is much greater than the adapter_trimmed_reads total), so I've been trying to dive through the code to understand this.

sentence: Fail to auto-detect read2 adapter?; I know insert fragments of my library is too short, and check that my Reads2 fastq contains many adapter sequence _AGATCGGAAGAGCGTCGTGTAGGGAAAGAGTGT_ but fastp seems fail to auto-detect this sequence? . ```bash. Detecting adapter sequence for read1... >Illumina TruSeq Adapter Read 1. AGATCGGAAGAGCACACGTCTGAACTCCAGTCA. Detecting adapter sequence for read2... No adapter detected for read2. ... Read2 before filtering:. total reads: 59690021. total bases: 8953503150. Q20 bases: 8379330202(93.5872%). Q30 bases: 7891608641(88.1399%). ... Read2 aftering filtering:. total reads: 57917482. total bases: 7208233787. Q20 bases: 7062332646(97.9759%). Q30 bases: 6786157015(94.1445%). ```. Here fastp trim (59690021 - 57917482) / 59690021 = ~ 0.0296957342333654 . And I use grep to count reads with adapter sequence. ```bash. $zcat WT1_R2.fq.gz | grep AGATCGGAAGAGCGTCGTGTAGGGAAAGAGTGT | wc -l . 4433330. $zcat WT1_R2.fq.gz | wc -l . 238760084. ```. So reads with adapter sequence 4433330 / 59690021 = ~ 0.07427254884028 > 0.0296957342333654 . Even after I add . ```bash. --adapter_sequence_r2 AGATCGGAAGAGCGTCGTGTAGGGAAAGAGTGT. ```. to fastp command still trimming too little reads. ```bash. Read2 before filtering:. total reads: 59690021. total bases: 8953503150. Q20 bases: 8379330202(93.5872%). Q30 bases: 7891608641(88.1399%). ... Read2 aftering filtering:. total reads: 57928915. total bases: 7199275770. Q20 bases: 7055842147(98.0077%). Q30 bases: 6781082455(94.1912%). ```
author: OpenGene

And I use grep to count reads with adapter sequence. ```bash. $zcat WT1_R2.fq.gz | grep AGATCGGAAGAGCGTCGTGTAGGGAAAGAGTGT | wc -l . 4433330. $zcat WT1_R2.fq.gz | wc -l . 238760084. ```. So reads with adapter sequence 4433330 / 59690021 = ~ 0.07427254884028 > 0.0296957342333654 . Even after I add . ```bash. --adapter_sequence_r2 AGATCGGAAGAGCGTCGTGTAGGGAAAGAGTGT. ```. to fastp command still trimming too little reads. ```bash. Read2 before filtering:. total reads: 59690021. total bases: 8953503150. Q20 bases: 8379330202(93.5872%). Q30 bases: 7891608641(88.1399%). ... Read2 aftering filtering:. total reads: 57928915. total bases: 7199275770. Q20 bases: 7055842147(98.0077%). Q30 bases: 6781082455(94.1912%). ```

sentence: fastp for mac os; Hey, In my R package ORFik I use fastp combined with STAR to align data, as this is the fastest combo I can find. But sadly mac users need to do their own trimming since fastp is not supported on mac os. Any plans to make it run on Mac ? :)
author: OpenGene

sentence: GATCGGAAGAGCACACGTCTGAACTCCAGTCACGTAACATCATCTCGTAT --adapter_sequence_r2 GATCGGAAGAGCGTCGTGTAGGGAAAGAGTGTAATCGCTGGTGTAGATCT --unpaired1 1_S1_L001_singlets.fastq.gz --unpaired2 1_S1_L001_singlets.fastq.gz --failed_out 1_S1_L001_failed.fastq.gz -l 30 -Q -y --cut_right --cut_right_window_size 5 --cut_right_mean_quality 25 -w 16`. This give a report like this:. > Read1 before filtering:. > total reads: 1000000. > total bases: 300000000. > Q20 bases: 265210120(88.4034%). > Q30 bases: 237863991(79.288%). > Read2 before filtering:. > total reads: 1000000. > total bases: 300000000. > Q20 bases: 217867400(72.6225%). > Q30 bases: 186389929(62.13%). > Read1 after filtering:. > total reads: 811011. > total bases: 166740824. > Q20 bases: 166036662(99.5777%). > Q30 bases: 161429716(96.8148%). > Read2 aftering filtering:. > total reads: 811011. > total bases: 136920093. > Q20 bases: 136066202(99.3764%). > Q30 bases: 130934145(95.6281%). > Filtering result:. > reads passed filter: 1622022. > reads failed due to low quality: 0. > reads failed due to too many N: 0. > reads failed due to too short: 377924. > reads failed due to low complexity: 54. > reads with adapter trimmed: 763879. > bases trimmed due to adapters: 35194909. > Duplication rate: 0.12957%. > Insert size peak (evaluated by paired-end reads): 300. > JSON report: fastp.json. >HTML report: fastp.html. However, when I count the reads in the resulting files, they do not sum up to 2x 1 million:. > seqkit stats *.gz . > file format type num_seqs sum_len min_len avg_len max_len. > 1_S1_L001_failed.fastq.gz FASTQ DNA 136,616 8,095,004 0 59.3 300. > 1_S1_L001_R1_001.fastq.gz FASTQ DNA 811,011 166,740,824 30 205.6 300. > 1_S1_L001_R2_001.fastq.gz FASTQ DNA 811,011 136,920,093 30 168.8 281. > 1_S1_L001_singlets.fastq.gz FASTQ DNA 136,616 16,948,652 30 124.1 300. num_seqs sums up to 947627 per sample, so 52373 reads per file have an unknown fate. Did I miss something in the manual? I'm a bit puzzled by where this 5% of the reads go
author: OpenGene

This give a report like this:. > Read1 before filtering:. > total reads: 1000000. > total bases: 300000000. > Q20 bases: 265210120(88.4034%). > Q30 bases: 237863991(79.288%). > Read2 before filtering:. > total reads: 1000000. > total bases: 300000000. > Q20 bases: 217867400(72.6225%). > Q30 bases: 186389929(62.13%). > Read1 after filtering:. > total reads: 811011. > total bases: 166740824. > Q20 bases: 166036662(99.5777%). > Q30 bases: 161429716(96.8148%). > Read2 aftering filtering:. > total reads: 811011. > total bases: 136920093. > Q20 bases: 136066202(99.3764%). > Q30 bases: 130934145(95.6281%). > Filtering result:. > reads passed filter: 1622022. > reads failed due to low quality: 0. > reads failed due to too many N: 0. > reads failed due to too short: 377924. > reads failed due to low complexity: 54. > reads with adapter trimmed: 763879. > bases trimmed due to adapters: 35194909. > Duplication rate: 0.12957%. > Insert size peak (evaluated by paired-end reads): 300. > JSON report: fastp.json. >HTML report: fastp.html. However, when I count the reads in the resulting files, they do not sum up to 2x 1 million:. > seqkit stats *.gz . > file format type num_seqs sum_len min_len avg_len max_len. > 1_S1_L001_failed.fastq.gz FASTQ DNA 136,616 8,095,004 0 59.3 300. > 1_S1_L001_R1_001.fastq.gz FASTQ DNA 811,011 166,740,824 30 205.6 300. > 1_S1_L001_R2_001.fastq.gz FASTQ DNA 811,011 136,920,093 30 168.8 281. > 1_S1_L001_singlets.fastq.gz FASTQ DNA 136,616 16,948,652 30 124.1 300. num_seqs sums up to 947627 per sample, so 52373 reads per file have an unknown fate. Did I miss something in the manual? I'm a bit puzzled by where this 5% of the reads go.
author: OpenGene

author: OpenGene

sentence: Duplication rate differs up to 30% from that of Fastqc for single end reads; I found a quite big difference in the duplication between Fastp and Fastqc. For all my ~40 SE RNAseq samples, the rate is around 10-30% lower in Fastp compared to Fastqc. Is there an explanation for this or is it a bug? ![tableScatterPlot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94687/94698970-1a59a080-033a-11eb-8235-061129769630.png).
author: OpenGene

sentence: Travis-ci: added support for ppc64le; Hi,. I have added support for ppc64le build on travis-ci in the branch . The travis-ci build log can be tracked on the link :https://travis-ci.com/github/sanjaymsh/fastp/builds/188597488 . I believe it is ready for the final review and merge. Please have a look on it and if everything looks fine for you then please approve it for merge. Thanks !!

The travis-ci build log can be tracked on the link :https://travis-ci.com/github/sanjaymsh/fastp/builds/188597488 . I believe it is ready for the final review and merge. Please have a look on it and if everything looks fine for you then please approve it for merge. Thanks !!

sentence: Add support for the Illumina NextSeq 550DX to the two color evaluator.; Adds support for the Illumina NextSeq 550DX to the two color evaluator. Here's a sample FASTQ ID string for the 550DX:. ```. @NDX550213:8:HHYV2AFX2:1:11101:14546:1021 1:N:0:0. ```
author: OpenGene

sentence: Add alternative plotly https src; There was a problem with fetching plotly.js lib via unsecured http protocol if generated html files are hosted on secured (https) domains. This is a browser restriction and below is chrome 85 console error:. _Mixed Content: The page at 'https://{mydomain.com}/fastap-generated.html' was loaded over HTTPS, but requested an insecure script 'http://opengene.org/plotly-1.2.0.min.js'. This request has been blocked; the content must be served over HTTPS._. This code will generate new script tag with **scr=https://cdn.plot.ly/plotly-1.2.0.min.js** and fetch plotly this way only if plotly lib from **http://opengene.org/plotly-1.2.0.min.js** is not fetched.

author: OpenGene

sentence: What comes first: trimming or Quality filtering ? ; Hey, . I generally use the pipeline for both trimming and filtering, . When trimming I generally use global trimming to remove a certain number of bases from beginning and end,. For the quality filtering, I filter by n = 0 bases and percentage of the read which is under a certain quality score. I wondered if I use them both, what comes first trimming or filtering? . Thanks!
author: OpenGene

sentence: Length filtering still performed even if --disable_length_filtering is turned on; I wasn't expecting any filtering to happen if I specify these options --disable_trim_poly_g --disable_length_filtering --disable_quality_filtering. . However, the HTML always reports that some small percentage of reads is filtered due to being too short. . Is this intended or...?
author: OpenGene

sentence: Adapter detection for PE reads - overlap analysis vs tail-end analysis; Automatic adapter detection and trimming is turned on by default in overlap analysis mode, as described in the AfterQC paper. . However, there's also the option --detect_adapter_for_pe, which does the same thing as for single end reads (look for 1 million reads and check tail ends to automatically determine adapters). The description of the parameter says that fastp will run a little slower if adapter auto-detection is enabled, but usually result in a slightly cleaner output, since the overlap analysis may fail due to sequencing errors or adapter dimers. If the speed of execution is ignored, which of the two options for adapter detection would be preferred/recommended? The default overlap analysis, or the tail end analysis? .
author: OpenGene

author: OpenGene

sentence: Adapter detection for PE reads - overlap analysis vs tail-end analysis; Automatic adapter detection and trimming is turned on by default in overlap analysis mode, as described in the AfterQC paper. . However, there's also the option --detect_adapter_for_pe, which does the same thing as for single end reads (look for 1 million reads and check tail ends to automatically determine adapters). author: OpenGene

sentence: Ambiguity in using `trim_* [int]` and `cut_*` option together; Hi, Thank you for this really excellent tool, which has become a regular part of my toolbox! I have a hard time figuring out what the consequences are from using the `cut_*` and trim_*` commands in parallel. As an example:. When using trim_front 7, and cut_front with a default window size of 4; . - does fastp then first trim of 7 base pairs, and then perform end cutting, based on the mean of the new first 4 bp and the "sliding on"? - does fastp cut the front, and then afterwards trim the new first 7 base pairs? Consulting the help page does not bring any answers to this matter, so I hope my question makes sense!

sentence: Regarding Adapter identification and trimming.; I have paired end fastq file from mgi sequencer using pcr free protocol. `fastp --fix_mgi_id -w 16 --adapter_sequence AAGTCGGAGGCCAAGCGGTCTTAGGAAGACAA --adapter_sequence_r2 AAGTCGGATCGTAGCCATGTCGTTCTGTGAGCCAAGGAGTTG -i 1.fq.gz -I 2.fq.gz -o fastp_1.fq.gz -O fastp_2.fq.gz -j fastp.json -h fastp.html. `. I explicitly mentioned adapters which are used in the experiment in the fastp command. sentence: trim front option to allow more than 30bp; Hello! I am very thankful for this tool as I use it all the time! However, I am running into some issues as I need to cut the first 50 bp of my reads but the program does not allow me . ERROR: trim_front1 (--trim_front1) should be 0 ~ 30, suggest 0 ~ 4. I see that this issue was brought up before [here](https://github.com/OpenGene/fastp/issues/121?_pjax=%23js-repo-pjax-container) but the issue was closed despite having some demand for this implementation. Is there a way to allow this in the program? Or what alternatives do you recommend?

sentence: Could you add an option to trimming polyT from the 5'?; Hello,. Could you add an option to trimming polyT from the 5'? I think it is useful for filtering polyT stretches coming from polyA tails in unstranded RNA-seq data. Thanks,. Haibo
author: OpenGene

sentence: Global trimming of reads to specific length; Hi, I have PE 150 bp reads, and I want to shorten them into 75 bp, can I use `global trimming` to do it? And after the reads shortening, I also need to remove the adaptors in both read1 and read2. I am not sure which parameter should I use `-t` or `-f`? `fastp -i read1_150.fq -I read2_150.fq -o read1_75.fq -O read2_75.fq -t 75 -T 75`. or. `fastp -i read1_150.fq -I read2_150.fq -o read1_75.fq -O read2_75.fq -f 75 -F 75`. Could you please help to check if the commands are right? Thank you very much!

sentence: How to disable filtering or post-filter QC? ; ```. if you don't specify the output file names, no output files will be written, but the QC will still be done for both data before and after filtering. ```. Any way to disable this, if omitting output file names doesn't do it? In my case we are not interested in any post-filtering stats, and in theory disabling post-filter qc could save us some time.
author: OpenGene
